Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(2) Summary

APIs are one of the essential ingredients of digitalization initiatives and organizations increasingly put API programs in place. The goal of API programs is to help everybody throughout an organization on the API journey, and to make sure that the API initiative is pervasive and strategically supported. There are some well-known patterns and anti-patterns that allow organizations to improve their API programs based on the experience with existing efforts. We look at some examples of API programs and identify a set of key components that should be part of any program.



Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

Scaling API Initiatives Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(6) Scale Matters



Scaling API Initiatives Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(7) From APIs-on-demand to API First

  • APIs are the digital representation of all capabilities
    • API-enable existing capabilities by using API Archaeology [Making API Teams More Effective; Getting Started: API Archaeology (1)]
    • Conceive new capabilities as API First [https://www.apiscene.io/api-business-models/api-first-the-essence-of-digital-transformation/]
  • Supporting teams significantly influences the digital transformation
    • Creating and managing guidelines [guidelines] that help teams with their API-related tasks
    • Running a program that focuses on products and the landscape
    • Providing a platform [Providing an API Platform (1)] that teams can build on
  • API programs are more than just technical enablement
    • APIs represent the mindset of building digital and flexible value chains
    • API value is realized when value chains create value, not when APIs exist


Scaling API Initiatives Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(8) Getting started is hard, scaling up is even harder



Scaling API Initiatives Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(9) API Programs connect Products and Platforms

  • API products are products with APIs built by individual teams
    • Each product is built on the API platform of the organization
  • API platforms [Providing an API Platform (1)] are tooling and infrastructure for API products
    • Mature platforms support all parts of the API lifecycle
    • Platforms evolve as teams and the organization change and evolve practices
  • API programs optimize API production by managing the API platform
    • Support and observe API teams and consumers
    • Maximize productivity by minimizing the effort required for standard API tasks


Scaling API Initiatives Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(10) API Program Areas

  • API programs are essential for scaling API initiatives
  • API programs have to cover various areas
    • Strategic Alignment [Strategic Alignment (1)] for aligning with other initiatives and activities
    • Organization & Culture [Organization & Culture (1)] so that teams can work effectively
    • Awareness & Adoption [Awareness & Adoption (1)] so that API usage is maximized
    • Observation [Observation (1)] for managing program impact and evolution
    • Providing an API Platform [Providing an API Platform (1)] for providers and consumers to build on


Strategic Alignment

Strategic Alignment Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(12) Strategic Alignment: Connecting the Dots

  • API programs exist to support well-defined API strategies [A Structured Guide to API Strategy]
  • They are an essential component but have to be aligned with other activities
    • APIs are an enabling factor but do not solve problems by themselves [https://nordicapis.com/five-common-misconceptions-about-apis/]
  • API programs have to be embedded in larger initiatives
    • The API strategy [A Structured Guide to API Strategy] defines the business goals for using APIs
    • The digital transformation initiative will set the larger context


Strategic Alignment Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(13) Example: API Audience

  • It is not unusual for API initiatives to focus on internal or external APIs
    • It is better to support both and just have different ways how they are managed
  • Understanding API consumers allows to create a more focused API program
    • Internal consumers are a closed set of well-known consumers
    • External consumers need enhanced security, scale, documentation, …
  • Program focus should be on the target set of consumers


Organization & Culture

Organization & Culture Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(15) Organization & Culture: Transforming the Organization

  • The motivation for APIs is value chain speed and flexibility
    • Teams get as much support as necessary
    • Teams get as much autonomy as possible
  • Organizational structure needs to support autonomy and loose coupling
    • Never underestimate Conway's Law [http://www.melconway.com/Home/Conways_Law.html]
  • Culture must move from building systems to creating ecosystems


Organization & Culture Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(16) Example: Making Decisions

  • Inception: Managing the pipeline for decisions
  • Choice generation: Identifying selection candidates
  • Selection: Choosing from the list of options
  • Authorization: Possible review and discussion
  • Implementation: Reflecting on making the decision
  • Challenge: Allowing exceptions and evolving options


Organization & Culture Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(17) Example Decision Maps

  • Choosing a programming language
Inception Choice generation Selection Authorization Implementation Challenge
Centralized Centralized Decentralized Decentralized Decentralized Decentralized
  • Choosing software development tooling
Inception Choice generation Selection Authorization Implementation Challenge
Decentralized Decentralized Decentralized Centralized Decentralized Centralized


Awareness & Adoption

Awareness & Adoption Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(19) Awareness & Adoption: We have no time for APIs…

  • The API strategy [A Structured Guide to API Strategy] clearly defines the API goals
  • The API program puts the supporting infrastructure in place
  • API awareness starts with understanding the business value of APIs
    • Everybody should have some knowledge what APIs are and why they matter
  • API adoption depends on both API providers and consumers
    • API program supports API teams with tooling and infrastructure
    • Consumers know how to find and use APIs


Awareness & Adoption Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(20) Example: API Consumption

  • Consuming APIs is different from writing self-contained programs
    • Dependencies must be managed responsibly to allow for API evolution
    • Exception handling is different because of different failure modes
  • API discovery and responsible API consumption [https://dret.net/lectures/api-days-finland-2019/] are essential for creating API value
    • Existing APIs have no value when they are not used
    • Distributed programming requires a different skill set from writing local code


Observation

Outline (Observation)

  1. Scaling API Initiatives [5]
  2. Strategic Alignment [2]
  3. Organization & Culture [3]

  5. Observation [2]

Observation Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(22) Observation: Continuous Improvement Matters

  • API programs are only as good as their results
  • Observation is essential for understanding the API landscape and ecosystem
    • Teams decisions for their API products
    • Consumption of products in the API landscape
    • API program usage (program as a product)
  • Observations should lead to insights and should trigger changes
    • Design for change is important for products as well as for the program


Observation Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(23) Example: Observe Exceptions

  • Observe which decisions are made when using the API platform
    • There should be some predefined choices and possibly an exception process
  • When the exception becomes the norm it is time to look at the options
    • Discuss the alternatives and reasons for choosing them
    • Consider adding/deprecating predefined choices


Providing an API Platform

Outline (Providing an API Platform)

  1. Scaling API Initiatives [5]
  2. Strategic Alignment [2]
  3. Organization & Culture [3]
  4. Awareness & Adoption [2]
  5. Observation [2]
  6. Providing an API Platform [2]
  7. Conclusions [2]
Providing an API Platform Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(25) Providing an API Platform: Foundation for API Activities

  • API platforms are the foundation for API providers and consumers
    • API providers find tooling and infrastructure for the full API lifecycle
    • API consumers find APIs and support for using them effectively
  • API platforms must be designed and built for openness and change
    • Requirements will change through observation [Observation (1)] of platform users
  • Managing the platform as a product helps with priorities and evolution
    • Which platform features will create the biggest value for the API landscape?
    • Release new features early and often to collect feedback from platform users


Providing an API Platform Erik Wilde (@dret): Setting up API Programs for Success

(26) Example: SDK support for APIs

  • Some organizations like to provide SDKs for APIs
    • SDKs can help with adoption for less API-minded API consumers
  • SDKs should have the same release cycle as APIs to always stay in sync
    • Manual creation of SDK results in better but expensive SDKs
    • Generating SDKs from API specs can be done with automated tooling
  • Platforms can provide SDK support as part of the platform service
    • Various cost/quality considerations come into play for the implementation
